body: IN parts of Brooklyn these days, even the dullest community board meeting can count on coverage by half a dozen local newspapers. The opening of a supermarket might draw a phalanx of photographers. These papers have their bigger stories, too. ''Rats! Super Vermin Are Taking Over the Streets'' shouted a recent cover of The Brooklyn Graphic. The
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; In Brooklyn, There's No Stopping the Presses

author: William R. Everdell teaches history at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn and is the author of ''The First Moderns.''

body: In the dark before dawn, when the priest bumped his pickup truck through town to wake everyone up, Monica Cruz groaned and put her pillow over her head. In New York City, as the assistant manager of a store in SoHo, she enjoys daylong access to cappuccino. Here in her dusty little hometown, there is not a cup of coffee to be had. Still, on that not
title: A Mexican Town That Transcends All Borders

body: Past the row houses and warehouses of Red Hook, just beyond two car pounds at the end of Conover Street, sits a dockside garden that is an oasis on the industrial waterfront of western Brooklyn. It is a place, called the Garden Pier, where people go to collect their thoughts or eat their lunch. Many discover it when retrieving their towed car from
title: Desperately Seeking Solitude; 'It's So Quiet, Nobody Bothers You Here'

body: An article on Thursday about three students' efforts to get into Stuyvesant High School misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood for Bishop Ford High School, which one girl considered as an alternative. It is in Windsor Terrace, not Bay Ridge.
title: Corrections

body: The Brooklyn man who was found dead in a subway tunnel on Sunday apparently died of a fractured skull and massive head injuries shortly after his disappearance on March 11, a spokeswoman for the city Medical Examiner's office said yesterday. Officials have not determined whether the death was accidental or a homicide. Subway employees discovered
title: Man Found in Subway Died of Head Injuries

body: For nearly a month, friends and family members have scoured the streets of Brooklyn for a trace of Peter Caragiulo, the 21-year-old Windsor Terrace man who went out drinking with a friend one Tuesday evening after work and disappeared. Transit workers found his body yesterday morning inside a room full of cables under a subway tunnel about 100
title: Man Who Vanished Is Found Dead in Subway

body: Few New York City spectacles radiate as much anxiety as the annual surge of eighth graders outside Stuyvesant High School, the educational Valhalla on the Hudson, for a one-shot, grueling entrance exam that many believe will determine the rest of their lives. The most recent test one icy winter day -- with scores released just last month -- was, as
title: PUTTING DREAMS TO THE TEST: A special report; Elite High School Is a Grueling Exam Away

body: Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means. Most of all, the Neuhauses wanted to believe it
title: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar

body: DONALD PIERRE could not find the home he wanted for the price he could pay in his old neighborhood, Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- the one that would work for his growing family and bring in a bit of rental income. But three miles east, in once-notorious East New York, Brooklyn, he found a three-family building on a 40- by 100-foot lot. And, in
title: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs

body: Family, friends and neighbors have taken to the streets to search for a 21-year-old Brooklyn man who went to work last Tuesday, went out for drinks afterward at a neighborhood bar, stopped at a friend's house and then never made it home. The man, Peter Caragiulo, has not been seen since 1:30 A.M. Wednesday, when he left a friend's house near the
title: A Brooklyn Man Is Missing, And a Family's Search Begins

body: In fits and starts over several decades, Park Slope has become a laboratory for both assimilation and gentrification. The Irish and the Italians once brawled on Fifth Avenue, followed by the Puerto Ricans, who elbowed into the mix. There were Jamaicans, and by the 1970's, the hippies had arrived, enticed by the lure of stately but inexpensive
title: Park Slope, Reshaped by Money; As Rents and Prices Rise, Some Fear for Neighborhood's Soul

title: SPARE TIMES

body: The Brinks security guards robbed of more than $1 million Tuesday at the World Trade Center did not perform well on lie detector tests given shortly after the incident, law enforcement officials said yesterday. Meanwhile, the third suspect in the robbery, Richard Gillette, was apprehended last night after he briefly left a Los Angeles-bound Amtrak
title: Lie-Detector Results of Brinks Guards Raising Questions

body: Two of the three men suspected of stealing more than $1 million from security guards making a delivery in the World Trade Center have been arrested, law enforcement officials said yesterday, adding that they were closing in on the third suspect. Although it is unclear how the suspects got past security at the twin skyscrapers to carry out the
title: Two Suspects Are Arrested In Robbery at Trade Center

body: Police investigators began scouring the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn yesterday after receiving dozens of tips from residents who said they knew the three suspects wanted in Tuesday's $1.6 million bank robbery at the World Trade Center. According to the Police Department, more than 56 people called investigators yesterday after pictures of
title: Tips on Bank Robbers Lead Police to Brooklyn
